chapter.title: Bibliography
chapter.para: Most of the information in this book has been extracted from the kernel documentation and source code. This is the best place for information on how to build and install the kernel, and is usually kept up to date when things in the build procedure change.

sect1.title: Books
sect1.para: There are a number of very good Linux kernel programming books availble, but only a few that deal with building and installing the kernel. Here is a list of books that the author has found useful when dealing with the Linux kernel.

varlistentry.term: Ellen Siever, Aaron Weber, Stephen Figgins, Robert Love, Arnold Robbins. Linux in a Nutshell, Fifth Edition. O'Reilly & Associates, 2005

listitem.para: This book can be has the most complete and authoritative command reference for Linux. It covers almost every different command that you will ever need to use.

varlistentry.term: Love, Robert. Linux Kernel Development. Sam's Publishing, 2004.

listitem.para: Robert Love's book covers Linux kernel programming with a broad scope. It is a reference which should be on every Linux hacker's bookshelf.

varlistentry.term: Bovet, Daniel P. and Cesate, Marco. Understanding the Linux Kernel, Second Edition. O'Reilly & Associates, 2003.

listitem.para: This book covers the design and implementation of the Linux kernel in great detail. It is more oriented toward providing an understanding of the algorithms used than documenting the kernel API. This book covers the 2.4 kernel, but still contains a great deal of useful information.

varlistentry.term: Yaghmour, Karim. Building Embedded Systems. O'Reilly & Associates, 2003.

listitem.para: This book will be useful for people writing Linux code for embedded systems.

varlistentry.term: Gorman, Mel. Understanding the Linux Virtual Memory Manager. Prentice Hall PTR, 2004.

listitem.para: Developers wanting to know more about the Linux virtual memory subsystem may wish to have a look at this book. It is centered around the 2.4 kernel, but contains 2.6 information is well.

varlistentry.term: Bach, Maurice. The Design of the Unix Operating System. Prentice Hall. 1987.

listitem.para: This book, though quite old, covers all the issues related to Unix implementations. It was the main source of inspiration for Linus in the first Linux versions.

varlistentry.term: Stevens, Richard. Advanced Programming in the UNIX Environment. Addison-Wesley, 1992.

listitem.para: Every detail of Unix system calls is described herein, which is a good companion when implementing advanced features in the device methods.

varlistentry.term: Stevens, Richard. Unix Network Programming. Prentice Hall PTR, 1990.

listitem.para: Perhaps the definitive book on the Unix network programming API.

sect1.title: Web sites
sect1.para: In the fast-moving world of Linux kernel development, the most current information is often found online. The following is our selection of the best web sites as of this writing.

listitem.para: This site is the home of Linux kernel development. You'll find the latest kernel release and related information. Note that the FTP site is mirrored throughout the world, so you'll most likely find a mirror near you.

This site hosts the source repositories used by a number of prominent kernel developers. The project called ``linus'', in particular, contains the mainline kernel as maintained by Linus Torvalds. If you are curious about the very latest patches which have been applied to the kernel, this is the place to look.
Linux Documentation Project web site The Linux Documentation Project carries a lot of interesting documents called "HOWTOs"; some of them are pretty technical and cover kernel-related topics.

This page contains many kernel-oriented magazine articles written by Alessandro. Some of them date back a few years but they usually still apply; some of them are in Italian, but usually an English translation is available as well.
At the risk of seeming self-serving, we'll point out this news site (edited by one of your authors) which, among other things, offers regular kernel development coverage and API change information.
Kernel Traffic is a popular site that provides weekly summaries of discussions on the Linux kernel development mailing list.
This site picks up occasional interesting developments in the Linux and BSD kernel communities.
This site is oriented toward new kernel developers. There is beginning information, an FAQ, and an associated IRC channel for those looking for immediate assistance.

The Kernel Janitors project is the place where new kernel programmers can learn how to join into the development effort. A wide range of small, generally simple tasks that need to be done all over the kernel are described here. There is a mailing list that helps new developers get these changes into the main kernel tree. This is a great place for anyone wanting to start doing Linux kernel development, but not knowing where to begin.
